msContents.summary: A Nepalese palm-leaf manuscript of the Cāndravyākaraṇa of the Buddhist grammarian Candragomin (probably 5th c. CE) with its most widespread and best known commentary, the Cāndravyākaraṇavṛtti, for a long time believed to be the work of Candragomin himself, but now generally attributed (Dash 1986; Oberlies 1989) to an author called Dharmadāsa who probably flourished in the 6th c. CE, but of whom nothing else is known. The manuscript contains the whole fourth section (pāda, literally “quarter”) of the fifth chapter (adhyāya), which comprises 176 rules. However, due to the very poor condition of f. 18v, only one of the final four rules, namely 5.4.175, āne mug ataḥ, is still legible, though barely, on line 4. A few words from the commentary on the final sūtra, 5.4.176, āsīnaḥ, can also be identified, followed by a sequence of much faded akṣaras that might be the final rubric either of the section or of the whole chapter five. The manuscript is not very accurate and even the text of the sūtras shows numerous spelling mistakes.

msItem.author: Dharmadāsa
msItem.title: Cāndravyākaraṇavṛtti
Cāndravṛtti
msItem.head: Main Text
Commentary
msItem.incipit: [1v1] || yor asakāra % kasya voś cānākāv ādeso bhavataḥ | nandanaḥ | gamanaṃ | kārakaḥ | kāccakaḥ | asa iti kiṃ | [1v2] kayuḥ | sayuḥ | yuvor iti samāhārasyaikatvād e % kavacanaṃ | vikalpānuvṛtter anapusakatvaṃ yudhabudhādīnāṃ na bhavaty anarthakatvāt_ | yaute yavayavaka [1v3] ketyāder jñāpakāt_ | bhujyur ity aunādikatvāt_ || @ ||
msItem.explicit:
[18v4] āne parato [18v5] kārāntasya mugāgamo bhavati | pacamānaḥ | % ata iti kiṃ kurvāṇaḥ | tapara iti kiṃ dadānaḥ | [-3-.]ty eva [-2-]
[18v6] -9- nipātyate | āsīnaḥ || || -26-

supportDesc.foliation: Letter numerals, mid-left margin, verso, ff. 4-6 and 10-17 (in the latter group, ten is noted with a short a, while the units are proper numerals).
Nepālākṣara numerals, mid-left margin, verso, ff. 1-3, 7-9.
supportDesc.condition: Probably complete, but the verso of the last folio is badly smudged and faded, and therefore hardly legible. The edges of some folios are broken.

layout.p: 5 to 7 lines per page, approximately 52 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: One string hole, to the left of the centre, inside an approximately 2.5 cm-wide blank space dividing the written portion into two blocks.
layout.p: Each sūtra (i.e. rule) is separated from the commentary on the previous sūtra by a double daṇḍa followed by a small circle and another double daṇḍa, and these elements are sometimes highlighted in red.

item.marginalia: A few corrections in the portion above or below the written area, usually accompanied by the number of the line in which the correction should take place.
On f. 1r, a few words and numerals on the portion to the left of the string hole and a few lines to its right, all of them hardly legible.

history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright in 1873-6.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
